sections.heading: A Multisite Strategy for Enhancing the Hydrogen Evolution
Reaction on a Nano-Pd Surface in Alkaline Media
Hanbin Liao, Chao Wei, Jingxian Wang, Adrian Fisher, Thirumany Sritharan,
Zhenxing Feng, and Zhichuan J. Xu*

Based on this mechanism, the alkaline HER is believed to be accelerated by introducing a water dissociation component that specifically generates protons.[5] For example, some efforts have been made to modify bulk electrodes, such as using a Pt (111) crystallographic surface with a metal hydroxide,[3] which was thought to promote water dissociation on the Pt surface.[3,5a] However, this limited investigation was on only a bulk noble metal surface, which has a low mass efficiency and high material cost. To date, there has been no success in engineering a noble metal nanoparticle catalyst with a water dissociation component to improve the HER in alkaline media. Efforts reported in changing the surface strain,[6] surface polarization,[7] coordination number,[8] facet exposure,[9] crystal
phase,[10] defect formation,[11] etc., have not yielded significant successes in alkaline media. A balance must be found between the water dissociation rate and the hydrogen formation rate on the noble metal surface to reach the highest overall efficiency. As these steps occur on different sites, protocols to fine-tune the areal ratio of these two sites on the nanoparticle surface are critical. Conventional “bottom-up” methods, such as wet chemical syntheses,[5c,12] have had some success, but a facile methodology for precisely tuning the areal ratio of the reaction sites on a nanoparticle surface is still not available.

The hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) on a noble metal surface in alkaline media is more sluggish than that in acidic media due to the limited proton supply. To promote the reaction, it is necessary to transform the alkaline HER mechanism via a multisite catalyst, which has additional water dissociation sites to improve the proton supply to an optimal level. Here, this study reports a top-down strategy to create a multisite HER catalyst on a nano-Pd surface and how to further fine-tune the areal ratio of the water dissociation component to the noble metal surface in core/shell-structured nanoparticles (NPs). Starting with Pd/Fe3O4 core/shell NPs, electrochemical cycling is used to tune the coverage of iron (oxy)hydroxide on a Pd surface. The alkaline HER activity of the core/sell Pd/FeOx(OH)2−2x NPs exhibits a volcano-shaped correlation with the surface Fe species coverage. This indicates an optimum coverage level where the rates of both the water dissociation step and the hydrogen formation step are balanced to achieve the highest efficiency. This multisite strategy assigns multiple reaction steps to different catalytic sites, and should also be extendable to other core/shell NPs to optimize their HER activity in alkaline media.

sections.heading: Electrocatalysis
sections.text:
The hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is a half reaction in electrochemical water splitting in which hydrogen is produced by reducing protons.[1] Hydrogen production from industrial water electrolyzers usually operates in alkaline media, 25–35% KOH electrolyte.[2] In contrast to the HER in acidic media, where the reaction rate is solely governed by H adsorption, the HER occurs in two sequential steps in alkaline media: producing protons through the dissociation of water and recombining protons to form H2.[3] The HER in alkaline media is a “multistep” reaction, and the slow kinetics of the first step make it the rate limiting step, causing a more sluggish HER in alkaline media than in acidic media.[4] This limitation can be

the elucidation of the effect of this ratio on the HER in alkaline media. To experimentally demonstrate this concept, we employ core/shell Pd/FeOx(OH)2−2x nanoparticles (NPs) as a tool. The Fe species acts as a site for water dissociation, and the Pd surface is the H2 formation site. The areal ratio of the two sites, which is a reflection of the coverage of the Fe species on the Pd NPs, could be tuned by electrochemical cycling, and the resulting composition evolution is monitored by in situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS). The HER activity of the NPs is then correlated to the areal coverage of FeOx(OH)2−2x via a volcano-type relationship, and the activity is 19 times greater than that over plain Pd NPs at an optimum composition ratio (equivalent to areal ratio) of Fe species to Pd.
The first step to prepare the core/shell Pd/FeOx(OH)2−2x NPs is the synthesis of the monodisperse Pd NPs via the reduction of Pd(acac)2 in oleylamine (Figure S1, Supporting Information). The resulting Pd NPs were spherical (Figure 1a) with an average diameter of 5.7 ± 0.1 nm (Figure S2, Supporting Information). Then, the Pd NPs were coated with a Fe3O4 shell by decomposing Fe(acac)3 in oleylamine. It can be seen that an oxide shell (low contrast) fully and compactly covers the surface of the Pd NPs (Figure 1b). The average diameter of the core/shell NPs is 9.5 ± 0.1 nm, and the shell thickness is 1.2 ± 0.1 nm (Figure S3, Supporting Information). The X-ray absorption near
edge structure (XANES) edge position of the Pd core in the core/shell NPs is the same as that of the Pd foil (Figure 1c), which confirms that the Pd core remains in its metallic state. Three investigations were conducted to prove the chemical nature of the shell was Fe3O4: (1) the X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) pattern of the shell matches that of the Fe3O4 NPs (Figure S4, Supporting Information); (2) the XANES spectra of the Fe signal are almost the same as the Fe3O4 standard (Figure 1d); and (3) the extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) curve at the Fe K-edge of the core/shell NPs is similar to the Fe3O4 standard (Figure 1d, inset). It is interesting to note that the lattice planes of the Pd core contract, possibly because of the lattice mismatch between Pd and Fe3O4. As a result, the Pd (111) XRD peak (≈40.8°) of the Pd/Fe3O4 NPs is located to the right of the pure Pd NPs (Figure S4, Supporting Information). This is consistent with the EXAFS results where the two Pd-Pd interatomic distances in the foil at 2.1 and 2.6 Å are shortened after the Fe3O4 coating (Figure 1c, inset; Figure S5, Supporting Information).
In the third step, we manipulate the coverage of FeOx(OH)2−2x on Pd by electrochemical cycling, which converts the Fe3O4 shell to FeOx(OH)2−2x and controls the removal of FeOx(OH)2−2x. This strategy is conceptually analogous to the electrochemical dealloying process,[8,13] but to avoid the

The potential applied to the Pd/Fe3O4 core/shell NPs was restricted to between −0.4 and 0 V versus reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) for the designated number of cycles. The Pt counter electrode was separated from the working electrode by an anion exchange membrane to avoid Pt contamination (Figure 2a, inset).[14] It is worth noting that the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements before and after the electrochemical cycling do not show a Pt signal (Figure S6, Supporting Information), which confirms that our catalysts are free from Pt contamination. After each cycling process for the designated number of cycles in 0.5 m H2SO4, a cyclic voltammogram (CV) in 0.1 m KOH was performed to quantify the electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) of Pd, which quantitatively indicates the Fe oxide coverage. As shown in Figure 2a; and Figure S7 (Supporting Information), the ECSA is reflected by the cathodic current peak located at ≈0.70 V versus RHE, which is attributed to the reduction of the surface Pd oxide layers (PdO, Pd(OH)2).[4] The CV curves (Figure 2a) clearly show that the plain Pd NPs exhibited the largest Pd exposure, while the Pd/Fe3O4 core/ shell NPs has an extremely weak Pd signal due to complete coverage by the Fe3O4 shell. Upon CV cycling, the Fe3O4 shell converted to FeOx(OH)2−2x, which is gradually depleted, increasing the surface area and exposure of Pd to the electrolyte. Based on the ECSA results (Tables S1 and S2, Supporting Information), we computed the coverage of FeOx(OH)2−2x (see the Supporting Information for the calculation method). As expected, with the increasing number of electrochemical cycles, the coverage of

FeOx(OH)2−2x decreases (Figure 2b) and reaches 35% at the 3000th cycle. In agreement with the CV results, the removal of the FeOx(OH)2−2x shell was also confirmed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). After 1000 cycles, the low-contrast Fe3O4 shell is almost absent, as evident in the bright field image in Figure 2d. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping of the particle also shows a reduced concentration of the Fe species (reduced green dots), but interestingly, the Fe is not completely removed. The size/shape of the Pd core remains unchanged (Figure 2d), and there was no NP aggregation, even after 1000 cycles (Figure S8, Supporting Information). A similar shell-stripping was evident when the Pd/Fe3O4 core/shell NPs were simply dipped in a stirred acid solution for 2.5 h without any applied potential (Figure S7, Supporting Information). The resulting coverage of FeOx(OH)2−2x was 64%, a value that can be easily achieved using 10 electrochemical cycles. Hence, our electrochemical cycling is an efficient method for manipulating the surface coverage on Pd NPs.
To further understand the changes in the areal coverage of the core/shell Pd/FeOx(OH)2−2x NPs during the electrochemical cycling, in situ XAS was used to monitor the structural evolution of the FeOx(OH)2−2x shell and Pd core. The NPs were first subjected to the designated number of electrochemical cycles in 0.5 m H2SO4, which was followed by the in situ XAS measurement at an applied potential of 0 V versus RHE in 0.1 m KOH. Under this potential, for 0 cycles, the Fe K-edge XANES spectrum immediately shifts to the left (Figure S10, Supporting Information), which signifies a reduction of the Fe ion. Measurements made at different potentials also showed the same edge shift in the Fe K-edge (Figure S10, Supporting Information), indicating that there is not a potential dependence of the Fe valence state within the electrochemical cycling range (−0.4–0 V vs RHE). Therefore, we use 0 V versus RHE for further data extraction. The valence states of Fe in the selected electrochemical cycles were computed using the integral method (Figures S11 and S12, Supporting Information).[15] It can be seen that the Fe valence state has a “V”-shaped relationship with the number of cycles with a minimum of +1.7 at the 1000th cycle (Figure 3a, inset). It should be mentioned that since the Pd/FeOx(OH)2−2x NPs with various FeOx(OH)2−2x coverage were initially prepared in 0.5 m H2SO4, the in situ XANES spectra were also collected in 0.5 m H2SO4 (Figures S11 and S12, Supporting Information) to determine the Fe valence state before transferring the NPs to 0.1 m KOH. The Fe valence
Adv. Energy Mater. 2017, 1701129
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1701129 (5 of 7)
states in 0.1 m KOH and in 0.5 m H2SO4 show negligible difference; they exhibit the same trend as a function of the cycle number. Because the HER activity estimation was conducted in 0.1 m KOH, the Fe valence state in 0.1 m KOH is considered to be directly associated with the HER activity (inset, Figure 3a).
The “V”-shaped trend of the Fe valence state is attributed to the evolving ratio of the divalent Fe on the NP surface to the metallic Fe within the NPs. Our XANES study observes that the average Fe valence state in the Pd/FeOx(OH)2−2x particle changed from +2.0 to +1.7, which clearly demonstrated the presence of metallic Fe atoms. However, according to the Pourbaix diagram,[16] the oxidation state of Fe should be +2 within the potential window of our electrochemical cycling (−0.4–0 V vs RHE). Therefore, the electrochemically accessible Fe species located at the topmost surface of the NPs should possess a valence state of +2. This excludes the possibility that the PdFe alloy is located at the outmost layer, which is electrochemically accessible and should give Fe2+. Thus, the metallic Fe should be located under the outmost layer of the Pd/FeOx(OH)2−2x particle. As proven by the above evidence, the metallic Fe layer should be present between the Pd core and the FeOx(OH)2−2x skin (as shown in Figure S13, Supporting Information). Because the metallic Fe lies beneath the FeOx(OH)2−2x skin from the 0 to 1000th cycle, it does not directly contact the electrolyte. Hence, the dissolution can only occur at the FeOx(OH)2−2x species. With a decreasing amount of divalent Fe, the average oxidation state of Fe drops. After the 1000th cycle, the FeOx(OH)2−2x skin becomes very thin, and the exposure of metallic Fe to the electrolyte is initiated. Then, the metallic Fe is oxidized to Fe2+, and consequently, the average valence state of Fe increases. The percentages of Fe2+ and metallic Fe were calculated and are plotted as a function of the electrochemical cycle in Figure S14 (Supporting Information). The percentage of metallic Fe reaches a maximum (15%) at the 1000th cycle where the average Fe valence state is the lowest. It must be noted that the overall metallic Fe content is quite small, which implies that the layer of Fe metal is extremely thin. To further support this explanation, the in situ EXAFS curves of the Fe K-edge were measured to monitor the local fine structure of the Fe shell (Figure 3b; and Figure S15, Supporting Information). Similar to the XANES results, the percentages of Fe2+ and metallic Fe can also be reflected from the intensity ratio of the EXAFS peak at ≈2.5 to ≈1.6 Å (Figure 3b). The peak at ≈2.5 Å represents the FePd bond of the metallic Fe,[17] and the peak at ≈1.6 Å signifies the FeO bond of FeOx(OH)2−2x.[18] It is observed that, qualitatively, the intensity ratio of these two EXAFS peaks increased from the 0 to 1000th cycle and dropped from 1000th to 3000th cycle. This trend is the same as the trend for the XANES results (Figure S14, Supporting Information), where the percentage of the metallic Fe and the electrochemical cycle form a volcano-shaped relationship. Therefore, the consistency between the EXAFS and XANES results solidly confirmed our hypothesis that the “V”-shaped trend in the Fe valence state is due to the evolving ratio of the divalent Fe on the outermost surface to the metallic Fe beneath the surface. To accurately describe the structure of the electrochemically active iron component, the shell is denoted as FeOx(OH)2−2x.
In contrast to the Fe species, Pd does not change its metallic valence state during the electrochemical cycling (Figure 3c).
When the shell dissolution occurs, the internal stress in the Pd core relaxes, and the lattice distortion disappears. As a result, the position of the Pd (111) XRD peak shifts back to the left (Figure S4, Supporting Information), and the Pd-Pd distances in the EXAFS curves are elongated (Figure 3c, inset). Hence, as revealed by the XAS results, the core/shell Pd/FeOx(OH)2−2x NPs undergo a structural evolution during the electrochemical cycling, but the electrochemical cycling only modifies the FeOx(OH)2−2x surface coverage, changing the exposure of the Pd surface area, without altering the chemical nature of the active sites.
Here, we discuss the HER intrinsic activity of the core/shell Pd/FeOx(OH)2−2x NPs as a function of the FeOx(OH)2−2x coverage. The HER geometric current densities of the as-synthesized Pd core, pure Fe3O4 NPs (Figure S6, Supporting Information), and Pd/FeOx(OH)2−2x NPs are shown in Figure S17 (Supporting Information). By normalizing the current density to the surface area of the catalyst, it can be seen in the polarization curves (Figure 4a) and Tafel plots (Figure 4b) that the Pd/FeOx(OH)2−2x NPs exhibit various HER activities. The overpotential to reach the geometric current density of 10 mA cm−2 (η@10 mA cm−2geo) is widely used for activity comparisons. However, it should be cautioned that η@10 mA cm−2geo cannot reflect the intrinsic activity; it is highly sensitive to the loading mass of the catalysts. Since various publications use different loading masses, the activity comparison, in terms of η@10 mA cm−2geo, is not rational. Therefore, we extract the TOF (turnover frequency), which is based on the surface area of the catalyst, and it represents the intrinsic catalytic activity, thus rationalizing the activity comparison. The comparison of the TOF with the landmark literature indicated that our Pd/ FeOx(OH)2−2x NPs ranked among the top alkaline HER catalysts (Figure 4c; and Table S4, Supporting Information). Additionally, our Pd/FeOx(OH)2−2x NPs possesses an excellent HER stability superior to commercial Pd/C and Pt/C catalysts (Figure S18, Supporting Information).
To understand the different activities of the Pd/FeOx(OH)2−2x NPs, the intrinsic activity is defined as the potential to reach a given current density (normalized to the surface area of catalyst), i.e., 0.1 mA cm−2 and is plotted against the FeOx(OH)2−2x coverage. It is proposed that the FeOx(OH)2−2x coverage is the HER activity descriptor because the metal oxide has been hypothesized to dominate the water dissociation step of HER in alkaline electrolytes. By plotting the HER activity as a function of the FeOx(OH)2−2x coverage, we observed a striking volcano trend (Figure 4d), which is attributed to the net result of the water dissociation step and the hydrogen recombination step. This two-step HER mechanism in an alkaline electrolyte has been recognized by studies on various metal oxide/Pt models.[3] The metal oxide promotes the water dissociation step (Volmer step, H2O ↔ H + OH− + e−), and the nearby Pt adsorbs the H (hydrogen recombination step, H ↔ Pt-Had) to catalyze the HH bond formation. In this study, the ability to dissociate water on the FeOx(OH)2−2x shell is also experimentally validated by comparing the fingerprint CV curves of the pure Pd with the core/shell Pd/FeOx(OH)2−2x NPs (Figure S5, Supporting Information). The H adsorption/desorption signal (0.2–0.6 V vs RHE) on Pd is weaker than that on the Pd/FeOx(OH)2−2x NPs, which proves that introducing the FeOx(OH)2−2x shell greatly
Adv. Energy Mater. 2017, 1701129
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1701129 (6 of 7)Adv. Energy Mater. 2017, 1701129
accelerates the water dissociation and generates more H to be adsorbed by Pd.[3] On the left side of the HER volcano trend curve of the core/shell Pd/FeOx(OH)2−2x NPs, there are enough Pd sites to catalyze the hydrogen recombination, but the coverage of FeOx(OH)2−2x is insufficient to meet the demand for the reactant H. Therefore, the HER kinetics are controlled by the water dissociation rate, which slows down the overall HER rate. On the right side, where the FeOx(OH)2−2x coverage is high enough to produce abundant H, but the Pd area of exposure is insufficient to convert all the H to hydrogen gas, the hydrogen recombination is the rate limiting step. Consequently, the overall activity is low. The highest HER activity is achieved at a FeOx(OH)2−2x coverage of ≈40%, at which point the water dissociation rate on FeOx(OH)2−2x and the hydrogen recombination rate on Pd are balanced by the optimized areal ratio of the exposed FeOx(OH)2−2x and Pd.
In summary, we present a novel top-down method to tune the coverage of FeOx(OH)2−2x on Pd NPs via electrochemical cycling to optimize the alkaline HER activity. The HER activity of various core/shell Pd/FeOx(OH)2−2x NPs in alkaline media exhibits a volcano-shape trend as a function of the FeOx(OH)2−2x area coverage, and the highest activity (19 times enhanced over
that in pure Pd NPs) can be achieved at a coverage of ≈40%, at which point the water dissociation rate and the H recombination rate are balanced for a maximized total efficiency. Our finding provides a “multisite” strategy to develop artificial catalysts to boost alkaline HER activity and other multistep catalysis activities on nanosized surfaces.

Conventional “bottom-up” methods, such as wet chemical syntheses,[5c,12] have had some success, but a facile methodology for precisely tuning the areal ratio of the reaction sites on a nanoparticle surface is still not available. Here, we report a novel “top-down” strategy to manipulate the areal ratio on a nanoparticle surface. This will facilitate The hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) on a noble metal surface in alkaline media is more sluggish than that in acidic media due to the limited proton supply. To promote the reaction, it is necessary to transform the alkaline HER mechanism via a multisite catalyst, which has additional water dissociation sites to improve the proton supply to an optimal level. Here, this study reports a top-down strategy to create a multisite HER catalyst on a nano-Pd surface and how to further fine-tune the areal ratio of the water dissociation component to the noble metal surface in core/shell-structured nanoparticles (NPs). Starting with Pd/Fe3O4 core/shell NPs, electrochemical cycling is used to tune the coverage of iron (oxy)hydroxide on a Pd surface. The alkaline HER activity of the core/sell Pd/FeOx(OH)2−2x NPs exhibits a volcano-shaped correlation with the surface Fe species coverage. This indicates an optimum coverage level where the rates of both the water dissociation step and the hydrogen formation step are balanced to achieve the highest efficiency. This multisite strategy assigns multiple reaction steps to different catalytic sites, and should also be extendable to other core/shell NPs to optimize their HER activity in alkaline media.
